item.content:encoded:
When Jessica Ko was head of design at Google and then Opendoor, she realized that her teams spent about 90% of their time digging around Dropbox looking for assets.

In many cases, theyâ€™d find older versions. Or they couldnâ€™t find what they were looking for. Or even worse, theyâ€™d accidentally pick the wrong asset.

â€œIt was such a chaotic process,â€ Ko recalls. â€œAnyone could go in and alter things and change folder structures around. It was a total mess, and just continued like that because there was no alternative.â€

As Opendoor grew in size, the problem became an even bigger one, she said.Â 

â€œDesigners were quitting because it was giving them so much anxiety,â€ Ko recalls. â€œDropbox hadnâ€™t solved it yet. Google Drive was not a good alternative either. Designers deal with files the most, and weâ€™re exchanging files constantly.â€

Besides the frustration and stress the problem of file storage and sharing caused, not being able to locate the correct assets also led to errors, which in turn led to lots of money lost, according to Ko.

â€œWe spent a lot of money on photo shoots because we couldn’t find new things, or people would have to recreate designs,â€ she said.Â 

On top of that, she said, designers werenâ€™t the only ones who needed to access the assets. Finance teams were constantly needing them for things like creating pitch decks.

So in 2018, Ko left Opendoor to set about solving the problem she was tired of dealing with by creating file storage for modern design workflows and processes. Or put more simply, she wanted to build a new kind of cloud storage that would serve as an alternative to Dropbox and Google Drive â€œbuilt by, and for, creatives.â€

In early 2020, Ko (CEO) teamed up with Alex Zirbel (CTO) to launch San Francisco-based Playbook, which she describes as the â€œDropbox for designers,â€ to tackle the challenge. And today, the startup has emerged from stealth and announced it has raised $4 million in a seed funding round led by Founders Fund at a $20 million post-money valuation.

Other investors in the round include Abstract, Inovia, Maple, Basis Set, Backend, Wilson Sonsini and a number of angels, including Opendoor co-founder and CEO Eric Wu, Gusto co-founder Eddie Kim and SV Angel’s Beth Turner.

In a nutshell, Playbook claims it can automatically imports, tags, categorizes an organization’s entire media library, in minutes.

When starting out, the first thing Playbook set out to do was attempt to reinvent the way folders exist for assets, with subfolders underneath. And then, the company set about trying to change the way people share files.Â 

â€œSince so much is done over email and Slack these days, version control becomes even more difficult,â€ Ko told TechCrunch. So Playbook, she said, has built a storage system that can be accessed by all parties as opposed to just sending files via different channels.

â€œFor years, these assets have been dropped into what feels like a file cabinet,â€ Ko said. â€œBut these days, sharing assets is much more collaborative and thereâ€™s different kinds of parties involved such as freelancers and contractors. So who is managing these files, and controlling the versions has become very complex.â€

Playbook offers 4TB of free storage, which Ko says is 266 times the free version of Google Storage and 2,000 times that of Dropbox. The hope is that this encourages users to use its platform as an all-around creative hub without worrying about running out of storage space. It also automatically scans, organizes and tags files and has worked to make it easier to browse files and folders visually.

Image Credits: Playbook

In March, Playbook opened a beta version of its product to the design community and got about 1,000 users in two months. People continued to sign up and the company at one point had to close the beta so that it could manage all the new users.

Today, it has about 10,000 users signed up in beta. Early users include individual freelancers to design teams at companies like Fast, Folx and Literati.

The nine-person company wants to focus on getting the product â€œrightâ€ before attempting to monetize and launch to enterprises (which will likely happen next year), Ko said.

For now, Playbook is focused on the needs of freelancers. The company believes that the exponential growth of freelancers post-pandemic means â€œcloud storage needs to be smarter.â€

â€œWe want to first solve that use case, and unlock the problem from the bottom up,â€ Ko told TechCrunch.Â 

Also, another strategy behind that initial focus is that freelancers can also introduce Playbook to the companies and enterprises they work for, so the marketing then becomes built into the product.

â€œThey can transfer assets and files through Playbook to their clients, who tend to adopt,â€ she said.

Thereâ€™s a way to pick the absolute best images for your content: Apply AI

Today, Playbook is helping manage over 3.2 million assets and says it has â€œhundreds of waitlist sign-upsâ€ every month.

Looking ahead, Zirbel said the startup wants to branch out into image scanning, similarity, content detection, previewing and long-term cloud storage and tons of integrations.

â€œThere are lots of interesting technology challenges when you focus on the creative side of cloud storage,â€ he said.

Founders Fundâ€™s John Luttig said when the firm first met Ko and Zirbel last year, it was â€œclear that they had a depth of understanding and thoughtfulness around file managementâ€ that his firm hadnâ€™t seen before. Plus, in his view, there has been very little innovation in cloud storage since Dropbox launched in 2007.Â 

â€œThe product leverages modern design, collaboration principles, and artificial intelligence to make file management much faster and easier,â€ he wrote via email. â€œGiven their design-centric backgrounds, theyâ€™re extremely well-positioned to rethink the user experience for file systems from the ground up.â€

Playbook, he said, is able to leverage recent advancements in computer vision and design â€œto build a far better product to manage and share files.â€
